items.title: Azure Voice Recognition API - Access Denied
items.body:
I'm trying to run ther microphone_recognition.py with the Azure APiI
I modified the _init.py_ script to add the Azure Function
Script is as follows:
`#!/usr/bin/env python3
import speech_recognition as sr

r = sr.Recognizer()
with sr.Microphone() as source:
    print("Say something!")
    audio = r.listen(source)

AZURE_SPEECH_KEY = "32  character key"  # Microsoft Speech API keys 32-character lowercase hexadecimal strings\

try:
    print("Microsoft Azure Speech thinks you said " + r.recognize_azure(audio, key=AZURE_SPEECH_KEY))
except sr.UnknownValueError:
    print("Microsoft Azure Speech could not understand audio")
except sr.RequestError as e:
    print("Could not request results from Microsoft Azure Speech service; {0}".format(e))

`
Obviously blanked out key. But I copied directly from my Azure Portal.

Results were:

**Could not request results from Microsoft Azure Speech service; credential request failed: Access Denied**

I added a line to init_py to print out my key and it print out correctly

items.title: Audio file passed with BytesIO is not supported
items.body:
I want to pass to AudioFile a BytesIO. Now because my file is an ogg and speech_recognition doesn't support ogg, I convert it to wav and then I give it as argoument. This is the code:

```Python
downloaded_file = file.download_as_bytearray()
final_file = io.BytesIO()

recording = AudioSegment.from_ogg(io.BytesIO(downloaded_file))
recording.export(final_file, format='wav')

with sr.AudioFile(final_file) as source:
    audio = r.record(source)
```

items.title: @Dave234322 there’s probably configuration in pycharm that you need to do to point to the correct Python installation. Try to run it from the terminal and see if you get the same thing. If you do you probably need to install pip.

import speech_recognition as sr

r = sr.Recognizer()
with sr.Microphone() as source:

    audio = r.listen(source)

try:

import speech_recognition as sr
import pyaudio

r = sr.Recognizer()

    print("can u speak??")
    text = r.listen(source)

    try:

items.title: OSError: [Errno -9999] Unanticipated host error
items.body:
It's killing me that a simple example of pyaudio couldn't work. I'm trying to record my voice using pyaudio like this:
```
import pyaudio
import wave

CHUNK = 1024
FORMAT = pyaudio.paInt16
CHANNELS = 2
RATE = 44100
RECORD_SECONDS = 5
WAVE_OUTPUT_FILENAME = "output.wav"

p = pyaudio.PyAudio()

stream = p.open(format=FORMAT,
                channels=CHANNELS,
                rate=RATE,
                input=True,
                frames_per_buffer=CHUNK)

print("* recording")

frames = []

for i in range(0, int(RATE / CHUNK * RECORD_SECONDS)):
    data = stream.read(CHUNK)
    frames.append(data)

print("* done recording")

stream.stop_stream()
stream.close()
p.terminate()

wf = wave.open(WAVE_OUTPUT_FILENAME, 'wb')
wf.setnchannels(CHANNELS)
wf.setsampwidth(p.get_sample_size(FORMAT))
wf.setframerate(RATE)
wf.writeframes(b''.join(frames))
wf.close()
```

the error report like this:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "D:/projects/recording/test.py", line 17, in <module>
    frames_per_buffer=CHUNK)
  File "C:\Program Files\Python36\lib\site-packages\pyaudio.py", line 750, in open
    stream = Stream(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "C:\Program Files\Python36\lib\site-packages\pyaudio.py", line 441, in __init__
    self._stream = pa.open(**arguments)
OSError: [Errno -9999] Unanticipated host error

The strange thing is that this code work just fine on my other computer. I'm thinking maybe something's wrong with the mic. 
Thanks so much!

items.title: Problem with microphone when using Speech Recognition
items.body:
I have a Jetson Xavier, USB Microphone and Webcam having mic inside. Totaly, 2 mics. I am using Speech Recognition. When I try to use both webcam and usb mic, mic on webcam is taken by software as default. I want to use USB Mic when I plugged in both devices. I have found its device_index and I have written into software. However I have got an error as:

 **"OSError: [Errno -9997] Invalid sample rate"**

This is my microphone:

**Microphone with name "UAC 1.0 Microphone & HID-Mediak: USB Audio (hw:2,0)" found for `Microphone(device_index=24)**

I have tried to change sample rate to 44100. Error has disappeared but mic did not work.

P.S.: USB Mic works normally when I plug in it alone. Code uses it as default. I have problem only when I have 2 connected devices.

items.title: discussion: Code quality issues with (some) fixes found
items.body:
I have forked the repo and ran DeepSource analysis on it by adding a `deepsource.toml` [file](https://github.com/pnijhara/speech_recognition/blob/pnijhara-patch-1/.deepsource.toml).
Where I found a total of around 100+ code quality issues.
- Antipatterns: 19 (3 of which can be auto fixed)
- Bug-risks: 5
- Performance issues: 6 (5 of which can be auto fixed)
- Security issues: 79 (65 of which can be auto fixed)

## Expected behaviour
Behaviour may remain same however, these fixes can improve the code quality of the project.

In all total number of issues are listed here - https://deepsource.io/gh/pnijhara/speech_recognition/issues/?category=recommended

Link to `.deepsource.toml` configuration file that I have added to the forked repo for running DeepSource analysis can be found [here](https://github.com/pnijhara/speech_recognition/blob/pnijhara-patch-1/.deepsource.toml)

Which of these issues you would consider high priority, and which ones would you want to ignore or consider false-positive?

I can send a PR with some fixes if you want.
You can also activate this analysis on your own, and have it triggered on each PR if you integrate DeepSource in the repo

Disclaimer: I work for [DeepSource](https://deepsource.io)

items.title: Error for SpeechRecognition
items.body:
Hi Guys,
I was trying to make this thing which typed whatever the user has spoken.But I keep geting an error.
Someone on STackOverflw told me that he ran my code and it worked fine.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/62178729/valueerror-for-pyaudio?noredirect=1#comment109991769_62178729
First it was giving an error but when I changed it to this:
 ```
import speech_recognition as sr

r = sr.Recognizer()

with sr.Microphone() as s:
    r.adjust_for_ambient_noise(s)

    while True:
        print("Start Speaking\n")
        audio = r.listen(s)
        speech = r.recognize_google(audio, language = 'en-US')
        print('Did you say: \n', speech, show_all=True)
```
But this leaves the line blank and cursor keeps blinking after the first print statement.

items.title: Can I do recognition from numpy array?
items.body:
I'm recording a numpy array `dt` and then writing it in .wav by code like this:
```python
dt = np.int16(dt/np.max(np.abs(dt)) * 32767)
scipy.io.wavfile.write("tmp.wav", samplerate, dt)
```
after that I read it and recognize by code
```python
import speech_recognition as sr
r = sr.Recognizer()
with sr.AudioFile("tmp.wav") as source:
    audio_text = r.listen(source)
    return r.recognize_google(audio_text, language = lang)
```

Can I do recognition from numpy array without using wav? Cuz it takes excess time

items.title: Upload i2s microphone data issue when adding line put data to firebase realtime.
items.body:
Hi everyone,
I am doing my project with I2s mic measure decibel then upload to Firebase pretty well but close to the end i face a really annoying issue.
The code run smooth and mesure quite accurate but when I add "result=firebase.put("/Audio","db",kq) it ran in 2s and encounter error. I tried change the chunk and rate value but nothing happened.This is my code:
#!/usr/bin/env python
import os, errno
import pyaudio
import spl_lib as spl
from scipy.signal import lfilter
import numpy
import time
new_decibel = "global"


## For web browser handling
#from selenium import webdriver
from firebase import firebase
firebase = firebase.FirebaseApplication(myurl,None)

''' The following is similar to a basic CD quality
   When CHUNK size is 4096 it routinely throws an IOError.
   When it is set to 8192 it doesn't.
   IOError happens due to the small CHUNK size

   What is CHUNK? Let's say CHUNK = 4096
   math.pow(2, 12) => RATE / CHUNK = 100ms = 0.1 sec
'''
CHUNK = 2048       # Use what you need
FORMAT = pyaudio.paInt32    # 16 bit
CHANNEL = 1    # 1 means mono. If stereo, put 2

'''
Different mics have different rates.
For example, Logitech HD 720p has rate 48000Hz
'''
RATE = 15000

NUMERATOR, DENOMINATOR = spl.A_weighting(RATE)

'''
Listen to mic
'''
pa = pyaudio.PyAudio()

stream = pa.open(format = FORMAT,
                channels = CHANNEL,
                rate = RATE,
                input = True,
                frames_per_buffer = CHUNK)
    
   
    
    
    
             

def update():
        block = stream.read(CHUNK)
        
        decoded_block = numpy.frombuffer(block, dtype= 'Int32')
                ## This is where you apply A-weighted filter
        y = lfilter(NUMERATOR, DENOMINATOR, decoded_block)
        new_decibel = 10*numpy.log10(spl.rms_flat(y))
        
        if new_decibel is not None:
            kq = round(new_decibel,3) 
            print(kq)
            
        else:
            stream.stop_stream()
            stream.close()
            pa.terminate()
        firebase.put("/Audio","db", kq)
        
while True:
    update()

Please help, I am appreciate you all.
Thanks for reading.

items.title: update thread workers
items.body:
works in windows and not tested in other environment

added sample rate and chunk size
added adjust_for_ambient_noise to remove noise
and it works

items.title: RequestError: recognition request failed: Bad Request
items.body:
My code worked yesterday perfectly. Today I woke up and went to run the python script again and suddenly I was getting hit with "Bad Request" errors every time I tried to run it. I even went on another computer to do a quick transcription of an audio file using different code and I still got the same error.
 
![Error_Capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28992122/81754852-89b71c80-948d-11ea-86b4-c8d4c770b397.PNG)

I haven't the slightest clue whats going on. Was I blocked for sending too many requests? Its been stressing me out and I would appreciate any help anyone can give me. Thank you.

items.title: Speech recognition most of the time getting stuck at r.listen()
items.body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------

When I run the example program using r.listen() for pyaudio, sometimes it runs the first time but then, after I interrupt the program and run it again, it gets stuck on r.listen(). I inputed my device index on the microphone class. I got it working with a program that only listens once and then ends, and it worked the first couple of times, but each time the time it took for the listen() function to end increased. The only thing I can think that I can try is to close the microphone stream because it might still be in use after the program is interrupted, but I'm not sure what to call for that. Also I would assume that it's supposed to close automatically after the `with `statement? I use a webcam as my microphone and tried it with arecord and it works fine. 
My code:
```
import speech_recognition as sr
# obtain audio from the microphone
r = sr.Recognizer()
while True:
    with sr.Microphone(device_index=2) as source:
        print("Say something!")
        audio = r.listen(source)
    # recognize speech using Google Speech Recognition
    try:
        # for testing purposes, we're just using the default API key
        # to use another API key, use `r.recognize_google(audio, key="GOOGLE_SPEECH_RECOGNITION_API_KEY")`
        # instead of `r.recognize_google(audio)`
        print("recognising")
        recognised=r.recognize_google(audio, key="my key")

        #recognised=input()

        print("Google Speech Recognition thinks you said " + recognised)
        request=keywordidentifier(recognised)
        if not request==-1:
            print(functionidentifier(request))

    except sr.UnknownValueError:
        print("Google Speech Recognition could not understand audio")
    except sr.RequestError as e:
        print("Could not request results from Google Speech Recognition service; {0}".format(e))
```


Expected behaviour
------------------

I tried to talk to the webcam, and as I said it sometimes worked, but most of the times I would leave it for a couple minutes and it wouldn't end the listen() function.

Actual behaviour
----------------

When I run this code in the terminal, this is the output:
```

items.title: feature_request(docs): Languages, pricing and limits of speech recognition engines/API
items.body:
### 1. Summary

It would be nice, if to SpeechRecognition documentation would be added links to these parameters of each [**speech recognition engines/API**](https://github.com/Uberi/speech_recognition#speechrecognition):

1. Languages by supporting engine/API
1. Pricing
1. Limits of free plan (if exists)

### 2. Argumentation

#### 2.1. Common cause

Saving a users time.

#### 2.2. Details

For example, I searched free (and, if possible, open source) speech recognition engine/API, that support Russian language. I was forced to manually search, which engine/API meets these requirements. It took a hour of my time. If information on supported languages, pricing and limits would be in the SpeechRecognition documentation, I would save an hour of my time.

SpeechRecognition has [**thousands downloads per day**](https://pypistats.org/packages/speechrecognition). Perhaps many users, like me, have spent a lot of their time to search for the required engine/API parameters.

Thanks.

items.title: how to give a audio numpy array as input for recognition?
items.body: I have a numpy array of an audio file which is read by scipy.io.wavefile.read. How to give this array directly to the recognition api without using sr.Audiofile and r.record(source)?

items.title: Currently voice recognition accurate rate is worse then Jan even using same *.wav file
items.body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------
1. I found voice recognition result has some difference with result from about 3 month ago.
I use one same file for recognition. -- file see as in attachment

Expected behaviour
------------------
- Server will return: "939 popsicle button on the headset if the code on your phone is for 73939 have the call button on the headset if the code" -- same as I got the result on Jan 16, 2020, the accurate rate is very good

Actual behaviour
----------------
- Server return result is:
"939 tap the call button on the headset if the code on your phone is 499 button on the headset if the"
-- this is a lot of difference with the result that I got on  Jan 16, 2020, and for this time recognition result missing some numbers. I have try a lot of files, all have same observation.
Is it any change on back end server to make this issue happen?

```

System information
------------------
comments: 
Could you help to have a look? 
Thanks in advance

audio file see as in below link:

[Record_Wave-2020-01-16_09_22_36.zip](https://github.com/Uberi/speech_recognition/files/4468754/Record_Wave-2020-01-16_09_22_36.zip)

items.title: Julius
items.body:
I'm hoping to use the Julius STT engine and the word "Julius" as a wake word.  I have Juius running.  Checking the issues on the Julius Github page shows how to fix their installation issues.  It produces the following output:

pass1_best: <s> julius </s>
pass1_best_wordseq: <s> julius </s>
pass1_best_phonemeseq: sil | jh uw l y ah s | sil
pass1_best_score: 107.246803
### Recognition: 2nd pass (RL heuristic best-first)
STAT: 00 _default: 18500 generated, 4081 pushed, 344 nodes popped in 102
sentence1: <s> julius </s>
wseq1: <s> julius </s>
phseq1: sil | jh uw l y ah s | sil
cmscore1: 0.764 0.673 1.000
score1: 89.203560
InternalError: CMN_realtime_update: param->samplenum != c->now.framenum

It can correctly identified "Julius" over and over.  So that should make a great offline wake word.

I'm not sure how to parse out the word however to kick off speech_recognition using gTTS.  I know this is not an issue with speech_recognition, but it could make a good addition; so that the microphone isn't sending to Google all the time.

I hope I'm not being a pain.  Sorry if this is totally inappropriate.  I can't use snowboy because I'm on Ubuntu 18.04.
  I can use any version of python in a virtual environment -- probably using conda.

My **SpeechRecognition library version** is 3.8.1

My **PyAudio library version** is 0.2.11

ALSA lib pcm_dmix.c:1052:(snd_pcm_dmix_open) unable to open slave
['HDA NVidia: HDMI 0 (hw:0,3)', 'HDA NVidia: HDMI 1 (hw:0,7)', 'HDA NVidia: HDMI 2 (hw:0,8)', 'HD-Audio Generic: ALCS1200A Analog (hw:1,0)', 'HD-Audio Generic: ALCS1200A Digital (hw:1,1)', 'HD-Audio Generic: ALCS1200A Alt Analog (hw:1,2)', 'USB Device 0x46d:0x823: Audio (hw:2,0)', 'hdmi', 'pulse', 'default']     

BTW, here's the link to my installation video for Julius:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A-oNmgJ7qcw

Thank you

items.title: SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED
items.body:
hi, when i try to connect with recognize_ibm, i get the following error:

Could not request results from IBM Speech to Text service; recognition connection failed: [SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed: self signed certificate in certificate chain (_ssl.c:1056)

how do I disable verification of the ssl certificate? thank you very much
